47:07 Caption: The referee blows his whistle for half-time, bringing to a close the first 45 minutes of the match.
47:59 Caption: There has not been much to choose between the sides after an absorbing 45 minutes. Let's hope they can continue in the same vein in the second period. In terms of the overall play, the match has been fairly even so far. The home team tries to find the weakness in the opposition's defence, especially with rapid counter-attacks, while the away team play possession football.

In terms of strategy, the hosts were waiting for the right moment to win the ball and launch a counter-attack. The visiting side adopted a possession style of football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In an exhilarating encounter at the Liberty Stadium, Swansea City hosted Liverpool in what proved to be a gripping Premier League fixture. The match culminated in a narrow 2-1 victory for Liverpool, but not without a spirited performance from Swansea that kept fans on the edge of their seats from start to finish.

As the referee, Michael Oliver, blew his whistle to signal the start of the match, Liverpool took the kick-off and immediately tried to establish control. However, the initial minutes saw intermittent play with the ball going out of bounds multiple times. It was evident that both teams were finding their rhythm, each attempt at a clearance or a throw-in showing determination.

In the 4th minute, Swansea's first opportunity came with a shot off target, a sign of their aggressive intent early on. Liverpool had to remain alert, as the Swans were quick to capitalize on any slight mistakes. By the 7th minute, Swansea earned a corner, and their persistence bore fruit. An accurate corner delivered into the box was met with a powerful header. Swansea managed to force a shot on target that nestled into the back of the net, giving the home side an early 1-0 lead. The stadium erupted in joy as the fans celebrated the perfect start.

Liverpool, now on the back foot, responded almost immediately after kick-off. Roberto Firmino had an immediate chance but sent his shot off target. This was a clear indication of Liverpool’s intent to claw back into the game. A foul by Swansea around the 10th minute granted Liverpool a free-kick, but they couldn't capitalize on it.

Gylfi Sigurdsson of Swansea was particularly in the thick of things, both committing and drawing fouls. His trip in the 12th minute didn’t go unnoticed by the referee. Swansea continued to be solid defensively, often resorting to clearances to fend off Liverpool's advances, while briefly threatening again around the 21st minute with a shot on target, although expertly handled by Liverpool's Loris Karius.

The first half also witnessed an unfortunate injury to Liverpool’s Adam Lallana, leading to his substitution by Daniel Sturridge in the 23rd minute. This substitution saw Daniel Sturridge enter the fray, hoping to make an impact. However, the physicality of the game continued, with both sides committing fouls and struggling to maintain consistent possession.

Liverpool’s captain, Jordan Henderson, was among those shown a yellow card for unsporting behavior around the 24th minute mark. Swansea created another opportunity around the 27th minute, with Borja Baston’s header just missing the target.

The game continued in a similar vein, with Liverpool attempting to build up play, but finding it difficult against a resolute Swansea defense. An attempt by Dejan Lovren in the 35th minute from a corner was blocked by a defender, showcasing Swansea’s commitment to maintaining their lead. 

Not all was smooth for the Reds; Daniel Sturridge received a yellow card in the 38th minute for a hard tackle. Liverpool pressed on, though, with Sadio Mane and Roberto Firmino both testing the Swans' defense in the dying moments of the first half. Yet, the Swans held on, with the first half ending at 1-0 in their favor.

As the second half commenced, Swansea kicked off with a renewed sense of purpose. Ball possession swung back and forth in the initial minutes, similar to the start of the first half. But it didn't take long for Liverpool to equalize. Shortly after a free kick earned in the 8th minute, Jordan Henderson lofted a beautiful ball into the box. Firmino, demonstrating expert technique, headed it seamlessly into the left post’s corner, bringing Liverpool level at 1-1.

Swansea continued to fight back, but the momentum seemed to shift towards Liverpool. Several substitutions were made to inject fresh legs into the game; Wayne Routledge made way for Modou Barrow, and Leon Britton was replaced by Sung-Yong Ki, reflecting Swansea's attempt to regain control in midfield.

By the 18th minute of the second half, it was clear that Liverpool had found their groove. The Reds won multiple corners and had a few shots on target, one of which was a promising attempt by Nathaniel Clyne on the edge of the box in the 22nd minute, though it was denied by Fabianski's vigilant goalkeeping.

A pivotal moment arrived around the 38th minute mark when a foul by Angel Rangel in the box led to the referee awarding Liverpool a penalty. James Milner stepped up to take the decisive penalty, slotting it confidently into the roof of the net to give Liverpool a 2-1 lead.

Liverpool didn’t let up; they continued their attacking play with Emre Can and Divock Origi being brought on to maintain the pressure. By the closing minutes, Liverpool’s dominance in possession and tactical discipline were evident, although Swansea didn't give up without a fight. Mike van der Hoorn had one of the last significant chances for Swansea, but his effort from close range went inches wide of the post, much to the relief of Liverpool's fans and players alike.

The match ended with the scoreline reading Swansea City 1 - 2 Liverpool. It was a display of tactical nous, resilience, and individual brilliance. Liverpool demonstrated their ability to fight back from an early setback, sustaining pressure and making crucial substitutions that paid off handsomely. Swansea, on the other hand, can take heart from a performance that saw them push one of the Premier League’s top teams right to the limit, reflecting the undying spirit of the side and the passion of their fans who filled the Liberty Stadium.

In conclusion, both teams exhibited their strengths and strategical approaches: Swansea with their counter-attacking prowess and resilience and Liverpool with their possession-based game and clinical finishing. The match highlighted the unpredictable thrill that the Premier League always promises to deliver. Each team will likely take valuable lessons from this encounter into their subsequent fixtures as they continue to strive for their goals this season.
